text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Swedish papers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Embers of a fire that burnt down the library at Linkoping over the weekend were starting to cool. Police are investigating the blaze which was believed to be arson but no arrests have been made.
- Labour minister Margareta Winberg has a hard task in front of her with the government's aim to halve unemployment to about four percent by the year 2000 but she remains hopeful.
- Swedish/British steel group Avesta Sheffield says the company is set for growth.
Managing director Per Molin says new, lower costs will be the best in the European market and the company will be boosted by investments of over three billion crowns in the next two years.
- Chlorine-free paper production does not give any particular benefits to the environment, according to a joint study by Stockholm and Gothenberg universities.
In recent years paper companies have spent large sums investigating chlorine-free techniques.
- Swedish shareholders' group, Aktiespararna, says it is seeking information from S-E-Banken and Handelsbanken over a weekend newspaper report that the two big banks are in tentative merger talks.
- The U.S. central bank's meeting this week could lay the path for continuing developments on the world's stock exchanges.
